block.p: Your June 14 editorial praising Minnesota's welfare-to-work program correctly identifies the components of successful welfare reform. However, you do not mention that the program you describe has been altered in favor of a less costly and more punitive approach.

Compared with the original Minnesota Family Investment Program, the new version lowers income eligibility, provides less training, decreases incentives, stiffens sanctions and includes time limits. These changes led the researchers who did the study you cite in your editorial to conclude that their original favorable results ''cannot be assumed to apply directly to the new statewide version of the program.''

Your June 14 editorial praising Minnesota's welfare-to-work program correctly identifies the components of successful welfare reform. However, you do not mention that the program you describe has been altered in favor of a less costly and more punitive approach.

Compared with the original Minnesota Family Investment Program, the new version lowers income eligibility, provides less training, decreases incentives, stiffens sanctions and includes time limits. These changes led the researchers who did the study you cite in your editorial to conclude that their original favorable results ''cannot be assumed to apply directly to the new statewide version of the program.''
In taking credit for the original program's success, while carrying out an inferior alternative, Minnesota's welfare agency is trying to get away with the classic bait and switch.
The writer is a policy analyst at the Oregon Center for Public Policy.
